title: COMP/STAT112 Notebook
text:
Welcome
Welcome to my online portfolio for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.

title: 1  Univariate Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking univariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

library(ggplot2)

simpsons_episodes = read.csv("/Users/nrittenberg24/Desktop/simpsons_episodes.csv")

dim(simpsons_episodes)

[1] 600  14

ggplot(simpsons_episodes, aes(x = imdb_rating)) + 
  geom_density(fill = "yellow", color = "skyblue", size = 1, alpha = 0.7) + 
  theme_classic() +
  labs(title = "                       IMDB Ratings of Individual Simpsons Epidodes",
       x = "IMDB Rating",
       y = "Percentage of Episodes",
       caption = "Created By: Nolan Rittenberg") +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(color = "skyblue", size = 14, face = "bold"),  
    axis.title.x = element_text(color = "skyblue", size = 12, face = "bold"), 
    axis.title.y = element_text(color = "skyblue", size = 12, face = "bold"),  
    axis.text = element_text(color = "skyblue", size = 10, face = "bold"), 
    plot.caption = element_text(color = "skyblue", size = 10, face = "italic") 
  )

title: 2  Bivariate Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking bivariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

library(tidyverse)

CA_Test_Scores = read.csv("https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/AER/CASchools.csv")

ggplot(CA_Test_Scores, aes(x = income, y = math)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(title = "California: Income vs. Standardized Math Test Scores",
       x = "Income",
       y = "Math Test Score",
       caption = "Created By: Nolan Rittenberg") +
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey"),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey")
    )







::: This is a bivariate graph that shows the correlation between household income and standardized math test scores in the state of California. Both variables are numerical. From this graph, it can be concluded that lower household income is correlated with a lower standardized math test score. :::

library("mosaic")
library("mosaicData")
library("fivethirtyeight")


data(bechdel)
new_bechdel <- bechdel |>
  mutate(clean_test = factor(clean_test, c("nowomen", "notalk", "men", "dubious", "ok"))) |>
  mutate(half_decades = cut(year, breaks = seq(1969, 2014, by = 5)))


ggplot(new_bechdel, aes(x = half_decades, fill = clean_test)) + 
  geom_bar(position = "dodge") +
  scale_color_viridis_b() +
 theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) +
  labs(
    title = "New Bechdel Test Over The Past 45 Years",
       x = "Years",
       y = "Number of Movies",
       caption = "Created By: Nolan Rittenberg")

dim(simpsons_episodes)

[1] 600  14

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)

ggplot(simpsons_episodes, aes(x = views, y = imdb_rating, color = season)) +
  scale_color_viridis_b() +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Which Seasons of The Simpsons Have the Most Views and Highest Ratings?", x = "Views", y = "IMDB Rating", caption = "Created By:
           Nolan Rittenberg") + 
   theme_dark() +
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgrey", color = "lightgrey"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgrey", color = "lightgrey"),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgrey", color = "lightgrey")
    )

title: 4  Quadvariate Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking quadvariate visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

CA_Test_Scores = read.csv("https://vincentarelbundock.github.io/Rdatasets/csv/AER/CASchools.csv")

ggplot(CA_Test_Scores, aes(x = income, y = math, color = read)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  facet_wrap(~grades) +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "gold", high = "blue") + 
  theme_bw() +
  labs(title = "Income vs. Standardized Reading and Math Test Scores For Grade Level, KK-06 and KK-08 In California Schools",
       x = "Income",
       y = "Math Score",
       color = "Reading Score",
       caption = "Created By: Nolan Rittenberg",
       ) +
    theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey"),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "grey", color = "grey"),
    plot.title = element_text(size = 9) 
    )

title: 5  Spatial Viz
text:
Use this file to generate a professional looking spatial visualization. The visualization will not perfect the first time but you are expected to improve on it throughout the semester especially after covering advanced topics such as effective viz.

library(tidyverse)

favorite_stp <- tribble(
  ~place, ~latitude, ~longitude, ~favorite,
  "Lake Merritt", 37.803114, -122.257574, "no",
  "Bishop O'Dowd High School", 37.752794, -122.154875, "yes",
  "Soccer Field", 37.820813, -122.234928, "yes",
  "Steep Ravine", 37.883492, -122.627942, "yes",
  "Sporting CP Soccer Stadium", 38.761197, -9.160796, "no",
  "San Sebastian, Spain", 43.315804, -1.989508, "no",
  "Jack London Square", 37.793694, -122.275878, "no",
  "Oakland Coliseum", 37.751346, -122.200996, "no",
  "Lake Atitlan", 14.709353, -91.186263, "no",
  "Lake Tahoe", 39.086824, -120.044983, "no",
  "Pheonix Cup Soccer Tournament", 33.448376, -112.074036, "no",
  "Macalester College Soccer Field", 44.935251, -93.168314, "no",
  "Barcelona", 41.402970, 2.174339, "no", 
  "Playa Las Tortugas", 21.341994, -105.242991, "no",
  "Evergreen Lodge", 37.876005, -119.858070, "no",
  "Wilder Fields", 37.866482, -122.192308, "no"
)


# Load the leaflet package
library(leaflet)

color_palette <- colorFactor(
  palette = c("orange", "blue"),
  domain = favorite_stp$favorite
)

leaflet(data = favorite_stp) |>
  addTiles() |>
  addCircleMarkers(
    lat = ~latitude,
    lng = ~longitude,
    color = ~color_palette(favorite),
    radius = 8,
    stroke = FALSE,
    fillOpacity = .85,
    popup = ~place
    ) |>
  addLegend(
    "topright",
    pal = color_palette,
    values = ~favorite, 
    title = "Nolan Rittenberg's Favorite Places in the World",
  )
